photo.title: The Golden Temple at Amritsar

photo.description: Golden Temple,Amritsar-Gurpurab Day Lighting The Harmandir Sahib (Punjabi: ਹਰਿਮੰਦਰ ਸਾਹਿਬ also Darbar Sahib (Punjabi: ਦਰਬਾਰ ਸਾਹਿਬ, IPA: [dəɾbɑɾ sɑhɪb]), also referred to as the Golden Temple, is a prominent Sikh gurdwara located in the city of Amritsar, Punjab, India. The present day Golden Temple was rebuilt in 1764 by Maharaja Jassa Singh Ahluwalia (1718–1783) with the help of other Misl Sikh chieftains. Between 1802–1830 Ranjit Singh did the sewa of adding gold plating and marble to the gurdwara, while the interior was decorated with fresco work and gemstones.

photo.title: Entrance to The Golden Temple

photo.description: Golden Temple, Amritsar - Punjab, India From Wiki - Golden Temple[1] (Punjabi: ਹਰਿਮੰਦਰ ਸਾਹਿਬ) or Harmandir Sahib[3] (Punjabi: ਦਰਬਾਰ ਸਾਹਿਬ), informally referred to as The Golden Temple or Temple of God,[1] is culturally the most significant place of worship of the Sikhs and one of the oldest Sikh gurdwaras. It is located in the city of Amritsar, which was established by Guru Ram Das Ji, the fourth guru of the Sikhs, and is, also due to the shrine, known as Guru Di Nagri meaning city of the Guru. The temple is surrounded by a large Sarovar (manmade lake), known as the AmritSar (Lake of Holy Water or Immortal Nectar). There are entrances to the temple on all four sides, signifying the importance of acceptance and openness; ostensibly, this concept is reminiscent of the tent of Abraham in the Old Testament—his tent was open on all four sides in order to be able to welcome travelers from all directions.
photo.tags: nikond80 punjab amritsar goldentemple harmandirsahib
photo.title: Golden Temple

photo.tags: amritsar india
photo.title: View of Golden Temple, Amritsar, India

photo.description: Gurpurab Day Lighting The Harmandir Sahib also Darbar Sahib and informally referred to as the Golden Temple is a prominent Sikh Gurdwara located in the city of Amritsar, Punjab, India. It was built by the fifth Guru of the Sikhs, Guru Arjan Dev, in the 16th Century. In 1604, Guru Arjan Dev ji completed the Adi Granth, the holy scripture of Sikhism, and installed it in the Gurdwara. Sri Harmandir Sahib is considered holy by Sikhs. The most holy text of Sikhism, the Guru Granth Sahib,is always present inside the Gurdwara. Its construction was mainly intended to build a place of worship for men and women from all walks of life and all religions to come and worship God equally.Over one lakh (100,000) people visit the holy shrine daily for worship.the golden temple is made out of real gold.
photo.tags: amritsar india goldentemple night holy gurpurab day reflections litup lit
photo.title: Golden Temple (Gurpurab Day)

photo.description: Located in Amritsar, Harmandir Sahib is considered holy by Sikhs because the eternal guru of Sikhism, the Sri Guru Granth Sahib, is always present inside it and its construction was mainly intended to build a place of worship for men and women from all walks of life and all religion to come and worship God equally.[1][5] The Sri Guru Granth Sahib is the holiest literature in the Sikh religion,[5] the tenth guru of Sikhism, Guru Gobind Singh, in 1708 at Nanded made it the eternal Sikh Guru and the leader of Sikhism.[5] Anywhere in the world where the Guru Granth Sahib is present is equally holy and precious to Sikhs.

photo.title: The Golden Temple, Amritsar.

photo.description: The Golden Temple (Hari Mandir) is the most sacred one for the Sikhs. Everyday hundreds of pilgrims visit the temple to pray and accomplish their mission. A magical place. Without any doubt one of my favorites places IN THE WORLD!

photo.description: Golden Temple in Amritsar, India. This is the most holy temple of Sikhism. I was beside a columnt looking for a good framing for the temple when this woman came and knelt down to pray. She also presented me this photo of the Temple in its context. One of the most impressive places I have ever visited in my life. It was a quite relaxing experience for me to walk barefot over the white marble listening the spiritual canticles through the megaphony of the temple and looking the people praying and walking arround the temple.

photo.description: A Panorma of the Golden Temple in the morning as the sun rises. The past week or so it has gotten cold all of a sudden here in Espanola. I think winter is coming. As I was looking through some of my pictures I found the above picture of the Golden Temple from my last trip to India in Jan 2005. It reminds me of winter. Every time I go to Amritsar I always take pictures of Harimandir Sahib. On this trip I wanted to watch the sun rise behind the Golden Temple and take some pictures. So I went up on the roof of one part of the wall that surrounds the Hari Mandir Sahib. It was really cold that morning and I was barefoot with only a small jacket. The cold cement floor didn’t help either. I was starting to really shiver with cold so I paced up and down the wall, waiting for the sun to start to show light in the horizon. Time seemed to slow as I waited. Then, as I walked up and down the roof trying to keep warm I discovered my source of “survival”. I found a spot which was kind of a vent where warm steam/air flowed out. It turns out that this was a sweet smelling exhaust vent for the Parshad kitchen below! Not only did it warm my feet…but the sweet aroma of parshad made me feel good. So there I sat, huddled over the vent, watching the sun start to light the morning sky over Harimandir Sahib, with sweet aromas of parshad in the air keeping a smile on my face. So the next time you are up on the roof of the wall above the parshad kitchen, waiting for the sun to rise, go look for the “parshad heater!” Hahaha….. The above picture is from that morning out in the cold, warming my ice cube toes with steam/air from the Guru’s Kitchen.
photo.tags: panorma widescreen golden temple dual screen amritsar sikh sikhism harimandir sahib
photo.title: Golden Temple Panorama

photo.description: The Golden temple is famous for its full golden dome, it is one of the most sacred pilgrim spots for Sikhs. Maharaja Ranjit Singh had the upper half of the building built with approximately 400 kg of gold leaf. The Golden Temple is built in the 16. century and it´s on an island in a pool called 'holy pool of nectar'. Erbaut wurde der Goldene Tempel im 16. Jh. Der Tempel liegt auf einer Insel im so genannten Nektarteich und ist mit Blattgold bedeckt. Photographed in Amritsar, India.

photo.description: The Golden Temple in Amritsar attracts a lot of Indian and foreign tourists. This was my first trip to this magnificent destination. I went here both in the night and during the day. In the night the golden temple glitters with reflections in the pond. Unfortunately, i was not carrying my tripod so could not capture pictures in the night. Its the biggest temple i have ever visited. The whole complex is atleast 5X bigger than what you see in the picture above. The interior of the temple is even more beautiful than the outside.

photo.description: The Harmandir Sahib also known as Darbar Sahib and popularly referred to as the Golden Temple is a prominent Sikh Gurdwara located in the city of Amritsar, Punjab (India). Originally built in 1574, the site of the temple was surrounded by a small lake in a thin forest. Now, the temple is surrounded by a large lake, known as the Sarovar, which consists of Amrit ("holy water" or "immortal nectar"). There are four entrances to the temple, signifying the importance of acceptance and openness. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harmandir_Sahib

As I was looking through some of my pictures I found the above picture of the Golden Temple from my last trip to India in Jan 2005. It reminds me of winter. Every time I go to Amritsar I always take pictures of Harimandir Sahib. On this trip I wanted to watch the sun rise behind the Golden Temple and take some pictures. So I went up on the roof of one part of the wall that surrounds the Hari Mandir Sahib. It was really cold that morning and I was barefoot with only a small jacket. The cold cement floor didn’t help either. I was starting to really shiver with cold so I paced up and down the wall, waiting for the sun to start to show light in the horizon. Time seemed to slow as I waited. Then, as I walked up and down the roof trying to keep warm I discovered my source of “survival”. I found a spot which was kind of a vent where warm steam/air flowed out. It turns out that this was a sweet smelling exhaust vent for the Parshad kitchen below! Not only did it warm my feet…but the sweet aroma of parshad made me feel good. So there I sat, huddled over the vent, watching the sun start to light the morning sky over Harimandir Sahib, with sweet aromas of parshad in the air keeping a smile on my face. The above picture is from that morning out in the cold, warming my ice cube toes with steam/air from the Guru’s Kitchen.

photo.description: from www.maps-india.com/pilgrimages/goldentemple.htm The throphThe Decorated Palki and Sawari Now begins the ceremony of bringing down the Guru Granth Sahib. For the occasion, a gold and silver palki (palanquin) is prepared. Attendants lay down fresh sets of silk and brocade coverings, and sprinkle rose water. The head priest of the Harmandir appears with the Guru Granth Sahib on a cushion on his head. The event is marked by the drumbeat of the Nigara. The procession solemnly moves across the plaza, through the Darshani Deorhi, and along the causeway, stopping as it reaches the main door of the Harmandir. The head priest reverently lifts the Guru Granth Sahib out of the palki, places it on a silk cushion on his head, and enters the holy shrine. This is the evening ceremony procession.
photo.tags: sikh goldentemple
photo.title: Amritsar Golden Temple

photo.description: Sikh bathing in the sarovar at the Golden Temple. The Golden Temple, or Harmandir Sahib, is the central temple for Sikhs worldwide. The sarovar is called Amritsar, from Amrita, or the nectar the gods drink to remain immortal, and sar from sarovar, or pool which surrounds a temple. Amritsar translates to "The pool of the nectar of immortality" and is where the city in Punjab gets its name. Amritsar is not far from the Pakistan border in India. Here, a Sikh is bathing in the sarovar.
photo.tags: india amritsar goldentemple sarovar travel harmandirsahib sikh bathe bath
photo.title: Amritsar Visit: Harmandir Sahib

photo.description: Golden Temple, Amritsar - Punjab, India From Wiki - Golden Temple[1] (Punjabi: ਹਰਿਮੰਦਰ ਸਾਹਿਬ) or Harmandir Sahib[3] (Punjabi: ਦਰਬਾਰ ਸਾਹਿਬ), informally referred to as The Golden Temple or Temple of God,[1] is culturally the most significant place of worship of the Sikhs and one of the oldest Sikh gurdwaras. It is located in the city of Amritsar, which was established by Guru Ram Das Ji, the fourth guru of the Sikhs, and is, also due to the shrine, known as Guru Di Nagri meaning city of the Guru. The temple is surrounded by a large Sarovar (manmade lake), known as the AmritSar (Lake of Holy Water or Immortal Nectar). There are entrances to the temple on all four sides, signifying the importance of acceptance and openness; ostensibly, this concept is reminiscent of the tent of Abraham in the Old Testament—his tent was open on all four sides in order to be able to welcome travelers from all directions.
photo.tags: nikond80 punjab amritsar goldentemple harmandirsahib

photo.description: Golden Temple, Amritsar - Punjab, India From Wiki - Golden Temple[1] (Punjabi: ਹਰਿਮੰਦਰ ਸਾਹਿਬ) or Harmandir Sahib[3] (Punjabi: ਦਰਬਾਰ ਸਾਹਿਬ), informally referred to as The Golden Temple or Temple of God,[1] is culturally the most significant place of worship of the Sikhs and one of the oldest Sikh gurdwaras. It is located in the city of Amritsar, which was established by Guru Ram Das Ji, the fourth guru of the Sikhs, and is, also due to the shrine, known as Guru Di Nagri meaning city of the Guru. The temple is surrounded by a large Sarovar (manmade lake), known as the AmritSar (Lake of Holy Water or Immortal Nectar). There are entrances to the temple on all four sides, signifying the importance of acceptance and openness; ostensibly, this concept is reminiscent of the tent of Abraham in the Old Testament—his tent was open on all four sides in order to be able to welcome travelers from all directions.

photo.description: A Sikh man contemplates the holiest site in his religion, the Golden Temple in Amritsar. The temple-- and, indeed, Sikhism itself-- has a bloody history, but it was one of the most peaceful places I visited in India. I stayed there for free, at the foreigner's dormitory, and ate for free, at the pilgrim's kitchen. Every day I walked around the temple and watched the turbaned pilgrims carry leaves laden with ghee as offerings; while people often stopped to ask where I was from or to ask for a picture with me, hardly anybody hassled me for money or sex, a rare bit of of tranquility for a young, solitary female traveler.
photo.tags: india amritsar panjab sikhism goldentemple religion
photo.title: golden temple

photo.description: The Harmandir Sahib[1] (Punjabi: ਹਰਿਮੰਦਰ ਸਾਹਿਬ also Darbar Sahib[3] (Punjabi: ਦਰਬਾਰ ਸਾਹਿਬ, IPA: [dəɾbɑɾ sɑhɪb]), also referred to as the Golden Temple,[1] is a prominent Sikh gurdwara located in the city of Amritsar, Punjab, India.

photo.title: Sunrise At The Golden Temple

photo.description: An early morning image of a cleaner working on the sacred pool that surrounds the Golden temple of the Sikh religion in Amritsar, Punjab State, India. An incredible tranquill and spiritual site despite the thousands of pilgims it receives 24 hours a day.
photo.tags: amritsar punjab india sikhgoldentemple
photo.title: Pool Cleaner

photo.description: The Golden temple is famous for its full golden dome, it is one of the most sacred pilgrim spots for Sikhs. Maharaja Ranjit Singh had the upper half of the building built with approximately 400 kg of gold leaf. Erbaut wurde der Goldene Tempel im 16. Jh. Der Tempel liegt auf einer Insel im so genannten Nektarteich und ist mit Blattgold bedeckt. Photographed in Amritsar, India.
photo.tags: sikh sikhs amritsar golden tempel temple indien india nektarteich holy pool nectar märchen märchenhaft atmosphäre holypoolofnectar goldenertempel goldentemple
photo.title: the golden dome

photo.description: A bird flies as a partial solar eclipse is seen behind one of the domes of the Golden Temple, Sikhs holiest shrine, in Amritsar, India, Wednesday, July 22, 2009. The longest solar eclipse of the 21st century pitched a swath of Asia from India to China into near darkness Wednesday as millions gathered to watch the phenomenon. (AP Photo/Altaf Qadri)
photo.tags: amritsar ind 2009722 日食
photo.title: India Eclipse

photo.description: A wide angle view of Shri Harmandir Sahib and the Holy, Sarovar at Amritsar, Punjab, India. My Sigma 10-20 allowed me to include the two ( actually, three. Thanx Anurag) 400 year old famous beri (Indian Jujube / Zizyphus Mauritiana) trees, the Dukh Bhanjani Beri, Elachi Beri and Baba Budhaji Beri in one shot! Also managed to get the moon in the frame! More on Shri Harmandir Sahib here: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Golden_Temple
photo.tags: amritsar darbarsahib harmandirsahib goldentemple punjab sikh holy sarovar india dukhbanjani babbudha shrine anawesomeshot shiningstar superbmasterpiece ysplix
photo.title: Beri 2 Beri

photo.description: In the foreground, the _Langer_, or food hall; every day hundreds (maybe thousands) of people from every race/creed/caste etc are fed for free, without obligation to return any favour. Midground: the central Gurudwara of Amritsar; background; the famous pearl of said Gurudwara, Sri Darbar Singh (the Golden Temple). Photo taken from the second floor of Sri Guru Ramdas Niwas, where hundreds of people (including tourists) are accomodated for free according to Sikh hospitality.
photo.tags: india amritsar temple
photo.title: Food first

photo.description: One of many dedications for/by various Indian military units scattered around the complex buildings surrounding the pool in which the Golden Temple sits. Golden Temple, Amritsar. Quite spectacular, very restful. The complex still shows signs of Operation Blue Star.

photo.description: Also known as the Golden Temple, sitting on an island in the Amrit Sarobar ("pool of nectar") from which the town of Amritsar gets its name. The dome is said to be gilded with 750kg of gold and is in the shape of an inverted lotus flower. This is the holiest Sikh temple. A longer exposure, looks nice though the water is blurrier.
photo.tags: india amritsar temple pool reflection
photo.title: Hari Mandir Sahib by night

photo.description: Also known as the Golden Temple, sitting on an island in the Amrit Sarobar ("pool of nectar") from which the town of Amritsar gets its name. The dome is said to be gilded with 750kg of gold and is in the shape of an inverted lotus flower. This is the holiest Sikh temple.

photo.title: Hari Mandir Sahib by night

photo.description: Also known as the Golden Temple, sitting on an island in the Amrit Sarobar ("pool of nectar") from which the town of Amritsar gets its name. The dome is said to be gilded with 750kg of gold and is in the shape of an inverted lotus flower. This is the holiest Sikh temple.
photo.tags: india amritsar temple pool reflection
photo.title: Hari Mandir Sahib

photo.description: Simon and I at the Golden Temple in Amritsar, India. (Dec 09)....its one of the most magical places I've been too and hope to visit again!
photo.tags: fish goldentemple text religion sikh feet barefoot toes two 2 steps
photo.title: Two Pair

photo.description: This is a view of the inner perambulatory area surrounding the Golden Temple. The healing waters, reported even to have healed leprosy in one instance, edge into the bottom of the frame. The red stones in the minaret (not sure if Sikhs call it a minaret) rise up against the background of the whitewashed clock tower. The numbers in the clock are completely different than the Arabic numerolgy with which Westerners are accustomed.
photo.tags: india amritsar travel southasia asia subcontinent goldentemple sikh holysite sooc
photo.title: the smallest pilgrims

photo.description: With the senses assaulted in India (dirt, smell, vehicles, animals, the masses of people, etc), Jimmy seeks solace at the Harmandi Sahib (Golden Temple). The Sikhs offer entry for everyone along with free food, water, shelter and cheap internet. To top it off, this place is open 24 hours a day. The rent here is as good as it's going to get.

photo.description: Punjab is one of the richest states in India. And it shows. We visited the two biggest cities: Amritsar and Chandigargh. And we witnessed the crazy border ceremony @ Wagah, near Pakistan.
